'Character'
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 3 Archive (PS2): Miscellaneous Q&A (Post New Questions Here): 'Character'
By Khift on Friday, April 26, 2002 - 03:58 pm:

While playing last night, I noticed something that I thought was interesting. Although I'd noticed this before, this time it sparked an idea. Please remember that this idea is nearly completely unproved in any way, shape or form, and that which is proved I'll add (Proven) to it.


CHARACTER


• As you speak to your monster, not only does it's willpower change, but another factor that I call character is affected as well.

• Aside from the fact that both character and willpower are affected by your reactions, they are completely separated.

• Character affects the reactions gained from certain responses (Proven). This can alter the fear/spoil (If they exist here, that is) and stress changes when these reactions are chosen.

• Character seems to grown in spurts. There just seems to be 3 forms of character, with no in-betweens.

• Signs of 'Good' character would be if your monster responds to a 2/3-4 food "It seems that it understands." and the reaction to "As expected!" from a Great is "It looks pretty confident." (Proven)

• Signs of 'Normal' character would be if your monster responds to a 2/3-4 food "It looks like it doesn't care..." and the reaction to "As expected!" from a Great is "It looks very satisfied!" (Proven)

• As for signs of 'Bad' character, well, I've never had a monster get down there. Lisa once noted that when raising a Pancho for the lifespan research, it refused to eat something. I think its safe to say that that would be a sign of 'Bad' character.

• Your monster's personality greatly affects their ability to change character. My Joker had the personality 'Pride', and never showed signs of 'Good' personality until senility set in and he lost that personality. My friend's Izuna, however, showed signs of 'Good' character with the personality 'Faithful' in but 8 months of life. My Durahan was even more exceptional - it showed these signs at 4 months with the personality 'Stoic'. (Proven)

• Training style may have an affect on character. If your monster is spoiled, then it may have a more challenging experience in acquiring 'Good' character than if it were at 'Normal'. It might be the same if you're being spartan on the poor thing.

• Character may also affect venture performance. I noticed that my Joker had some problems with finding good venture items, but my Durahan found 3 Big Scales within moments, and good ones too. Also, this could explain Campster's failure with BruceLee, as Dragons usually start with the personality 'Pride', which is what impeded my Joker's trek to 'Good' personality.



Could some others comment on this? Have others noticed this as well? I'd really like to hear what you guys think about this.
By torey_luvullo on Friday, April 26, 2002 - 05:49 pm:

i've noticed these different reactions too. right now, all i can say is thanx for taking the time to list them. unlike the failure reactions, which i have paid a lot of attention to, i really dont have enough memory of how my monsters were doing when they got the differing reactions you describe to comment one way or another. i'll try to pay more attention with my future monsters.

By Pixie Misa on Monday, April 4, 2005 - 03:36 am:

I've noticed that if you get up to a "good" character (ie: "it seems it understands" when fed a 2/3-4 food) with a young monster, if they then change their personality when they grow a step (for example, all the pure pixies I've seen start with "indignant" and they often lose that and just go to "normal" when they grow the first time) their character will revert to "normal" (ie: "it doesn't care.")
